verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:1
verses.text: Church History of Eusebius, Book V.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:2
verses.text: Introduction.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:3
verses.text: Soter, bishop of the church of Rome, died after an episcopate of eight years, and was succeeded by Eleutherus, the twelfth from the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:4
verses.text: In the seventeenth year of the Emperor Antoninus Verus, the persecution of our people was rekindled more fiercely in certain districts on account of an insurrection of the masses in the cities; and judging by the number in a single nation, myriads suffered martyrdom throughout the world.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:5
verses.text: A record of this was written for posterity, and in truth it is worthy of perpetual remembrance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:6
verses.text: A full account, containing the most reliable information on the subject, is given in our Collection of Martyrdoms, which constitutes a narrative instructive as well as historical.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:7
verses.text: I will repeat here such portions of this account as may be needful for the present purpose.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:8
verses.text: Other writers of history record the victories of war and trophies won from enemies, the skill of generals, and the manly bravery of soldiers, defiled with blood and with innumerable slaughters for the sake of children and country and other possessions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:9
verses.text: But our narrative of the government of God will record in ineffaceable letters the most peaceful wars waged in behalf of the peace of the soul, and will tell of men doing brave deeds for truth rather than country, and for piety rather than dearest friends.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 1:10
verses.text: It will hand down to imperishable remembrance the discipline and the much-tried fortitude of the athletes of religion, the trophies won from demons, the victories over invisible enemies, and the crowns placed upon all their heads.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:1
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:2
verses.text: â€”The Number of those who fought for Religion in Gaul Under Verus and the Nature of their Conflicts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:3
verses.text: The country in which the arena was prepared for them was Gaul, of which Lyons and Vienne are the principal and most celebrated cities.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:4
verses.text: The Rhone passes through both of them, flowing in a broad stream through the entire region.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:5
verses.text: The most celebrated churches in that country sent an account of the witnesses to the churches in Asia and Phrygia, relating in the following manner what was done among them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:6
verses.text: I will give their own words.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:7
verses.text: "The servants of Christ residing at Vienne and Lyons, in Gaul, to the brethren through out Asia and Phrygia, who hold the same faith and hope of redemption, peace and grace and glory from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:8
verses.text: Then, having related some other matters, they begin their account in this manner: "The greatness of the tribulation in this region, and the fury of the heathen against the saints, and the sufferings of the blessed witnesses, we cannot recount accurately, nor indeed could they possibly be recorded.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:9
verses.text: For with all his might the adversary fell upon us, giving us a foretaste of his unbridled activity at his future coming.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:10
verses.text: He endeavored in every manner to practice and exercise his servants against the servants of God, not only shutting us out from houses and baths and markets, but forbidding any of us to be seen in any place whatever.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:11
verses.text: But the grace of God led the conflict against him, and delivered the weak, and set them as firm pillars, able through patience to endure all the wrath of the Evil One.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:12
verses.text: And they joined battle with him, undergoing all kinds of shame and injury; and regarding their great sufferings as little, they hastened to Christ, manifesting truly that 'the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed to us-ward.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:14
verses.text: First of all, they endured nobly the injuries heaped upon them by the populace; clamors and blows and draggings and robberies and stonings and imprisonments, and all things which an infuriated mob delight in inflicting on enemies and adversaries.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:15
verses.text: Then, being taken to the forum by the chiliarch and the authorities of the city, they were examined in the presence of the whole multitude, and having confessed, they were imprisoned until the arrival of the governor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:16
verses.text: When, afterwards, they were brought before him, and he treated us with the utmost cruelty, Vettius Epagathus, one of the brethren, and a man filled with love for God and his neighbor, interfered.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:17
verses.text: His life was so consistent that, although young, he had attained a reputation equal to that of the elder Zacharias: for he 'walked in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless,' and was untiring in every good work for his neighbor, zealous for God and fervent in spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:18
verses.text: Such being his character, he could not endure the unreasonable judgment against us, but was filled with indignation, and asked to be permitted to testify in behalf of his brethren, that there is among us nothing ungodly or impious.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:19
verses.text: But those about the judgment seat cried out against him, for he was a man of distinction; and the governor refused to grant his just request, and merely asked if he also were a Christian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:20
verses.text: And he, confessing this with a loud voice, was himself taken into the order of the witnesses, being called the Advocate of the Christians, but having the Advocate in himself, the Spirit more abundantly than Zacharias.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:21
verses.text: He showed this by the fullness of his love, being well pleased even to lay down his life in defense of the brethren.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:22
verses.text: For he was and is a true disciple of Christ, 'following the Lamb whithersoever he goeth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:24
verses.text: "Then the others were divided, and the proto-witnesses were manifestly ready, and finished their confession with all eagerness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:25
verses.text: But some appeared unprepared and untrained, weak as yet, and unable to endure so great a conflict.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:26
verses.text: About ten of these proved abortions, causing us great grief and sorrow beyond measure, and impairing the zeal of the others who had not yet been seized, but who, though suffering all kinds of affliction, continued constantly with the witnesses and did not forsake them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:27
verses.text: Then all of us feared greatly on account of uncertainty as to their confession; not because we dreaded the sufferings to be endured, but because we looked to the end, and were afraid that some of them might fall away.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:28
verses.text: But those who were worthy were seized day by day, filling up their number, so that all the zealous persons, and those through whom especially our affairs had been established, were collected together out of the two churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:29
verses.text: And some of our heathen servants also were seized, as the governor had commanded that all of us should be examined publicly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:30
verses.text: These, being ensnared by Satan, and fearing for themselves the tortures which they beheld the saints endure, and being also urged on by the soldiers, accused us falsely of Thyestean banquets and oedipodean intercourse, and of deeds which are not only unlawful for us to speak of or to think, but which we cannot believe were ever done by men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:31
verses.text: When these accusations were reported, all the people raged like wild beasts against us, so that even if any had before been moderate on account of friendship, they were now exceedingly furious and gnashed their teeth against us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:32
verses.text: And that which was spoken by our Lord was fulfilled: 'The time will come when whosoever killeth you will think that he doeth God service.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:34
verses.text: Then finally the holy witnesses endured sufferings beyond description, Satan striving earnestly that some of the slanders might be uttered by them also.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:35
verses.text: "But the whole wrath of the populace, and governor, and soldiers was aroused exceedingly against Sanctus, the deacon from Vienne, and Maturus, a late convert, yet a noble combatant, and against Attalus, a native of Pergamos where he had always been a pillar and foundation, and Blandina, through whom Christ showed that things which appear mean and obscure and despicable to men are with God of great glory, through love toward him manifested in power, and not boasting in appearance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:36
verses.text: For while we all trembled, and her earthly mistress, who was herself also one of the witnesses, feared that on account of the weakness of her body, she would be unable to make bold confession, Blandina was filled with such power as to be delivered and raised above those who were torturing her by turns from morning till evening in every manner, so that they acknowledged that they were conquered, and could do nothing more to her.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:37
verses.text: And they were astonished at her endurance, as her entire body was mangled and broken; and they testified that one of these forms of torture was sufficient to destroy life, not to speak of so many and so great sufferings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:38
verses.text: But the blessed woman, like a noble athlete, renewed her strength in her confession; and her comfort and recreation and relief from the pain of her sufferings was in exclaiming, 'I am a Christian, and there is nothing vile done by us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:40
verses.text: "But Sanctus also endured marvelously and superhumanly all the outrages which he suffered.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:41
verses.text: While the wicked men hoped, by the continuance and severity of his tortures to wring something from him which he ought not to say, he girded himself against them with such firmness that he would not even tell his name, or the nation or city to which he belonged, or whether he was bond or free, but answered in the Roman tongue to all their questions, 'I am a Christian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:42
verses.text: ' He confessed this instead of name and city and race and everything besides, and the people heard from him no other word.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:43
verses.text: There arose therefore on the part of the governor and his tormentors a great desire to conquer him; but having nothing more that they could do to him, they finally fastened red-hot brazen plates to the most tender parts of his body.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:44
verses.text: And these indeed were burned, but he continued unbending and unyielding, firm in his confession, and refreshed and strengthened by the heavenly fountain of the water of life, flowing from the bowels of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:45
verses.text: And his body was a witness of his sufferings, being one complete wound and bruise, drawn out of shape, and altogether unlike a human form.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:46
verses.text: Christ, suffering in him, manifested his glory, delivering him from his adversary, and making him an ensample for the others, showing that nothing is fearful where the love of the Father is, and nothing painful where there is the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:47
verses.text: For when the wicked men tortured him a second time after some days, supposing that with his body swollen and inflamed to such a degree that he could not bear the touch of a hand, if they should again apply the same instruments, they would overcome him, or at least by his death under his sufferings others would be made afraid, not only did not this occur, but, contrary to all human expectation, his body arose and stood erect in the midst of the subsequent torments, and resumed its original appearance and the use of its limbs, so that, through the grace of Christ, these second sufferings became to him, not torture, but healing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:48
verses.text: "But the devil, thinking that he had already consumed Biblias, who was one of those who had denied Christ, desiring to increase her condemnation through the utterance of blasphemy, brought her again to the torture, to compel her, as already feeble and weak, to report impious things concerning us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:49
verses.text: But she recovered herself under the suffering, and as if awaking from a deep sleep, and reminded by the present anguish of the eternal punishment in hell, she contradicted the blasphemers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:50
verses.text: 'How,' she said, 'could those eat children who do not think it lawful to taste the blood even of irrational animals?' And thenceforward she confessed herself a Christian, and was given a place in the order of the witnesses.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:51
verses.text: "But as the tyrannical tortures were made by Christ of none effect through the patience of the blessed, the devil invented other contrivances,â€”confinement in the dark and most loathsome parts of the prison, stretching of the feet to the fifth hole in the stocks, and the other outrages which his servants are accustomed to inflict upon the prisoners when furious and filled with the devil.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:52
verses.text: A great many were suffocated in prison, being chosen by the Lord for this manner of death, that he might manifest in them his glory.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:53
verses.text: For some, though they had been tortured so cruelly that it seemed impossible that they could live, even with the most careful nursing, yet, destitute of human attention, remained in the prison, being strengthened by the Lord, and invigorated both in body and soul; and they exhorted and encouraged the rest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:54
verses.text: But such as were young, and arrested recently, so that their bodies had not become accustomed to torture, were unable to endure the severity of their confinement, and died in prison.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:55
verses.text: "The blessed Pothinus, who had been entrusted with the bishopric of Lyons, was dragged to the judgment seat.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:56
verses.text: He was more than ninety years of age, and very infirm, scarcely indeed able to breathe because of physical weakness; but he was strengthened by spiritual zeal through his earnest desire for martyrdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:57
verses.text: Though his body was worn out by old age and disease, his life was preserved that Christ might triumph in it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:58
verses.text: When he was brought by the soldiers to the tribunal, accompanied by the civil magistrates and a multitude who shouted against him in every manner as if he were Christ himself, he bore noble witness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:59
verses.text: Being asked by the governor, Who was the God of the Christians, he replied, 'If thou art worthy, thou shalt know.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:60
verses.text: ' Then he was dragged away harshly, and received blows of every kind.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:61
verses.text: Those near him struck him with their hands and feet, regardless of his age; and those at a distance hurled at him whatever they could seize; all of them thinking that they would be guilty of great wickedness and impiety if any possible abuse were omitted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:62
verses.text: For thus they thought to avenge their own deities.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:63
verses.text: Scarcely able to breathe, he was cast into prison and died after two days.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:64
verses.text: "Then a certain great dispensation of God occurred, and the compassion of Jesus appeared beyond measure, in a manner rarely seen among the brotherhood, but not beyond the power of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:65
verses.text: For those who had recanted at their first arrest were imprisoned with the others, and endured terrible sufferings, so that their denial was of no profit to them even for the present.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:66
verses.text: But those who confessed what they were were imprisoned as Christians, no other accusation being brought against them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:67
verses.text: But the first were treated afterwards as murderers and defiled, and were punished twice as severely as the others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:68
verses.text: For the joy of martyrdom, and the hope of the promises, and love for Christ, and the Spirit of the Father supported the latter; but their consciences so greatly distressed the former that they were easily distinguishable from all the rest by their very countenances when they were led forth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:69
verses.text: For the first went out rejoicing, glory and grace being blended in their faces, so that even their bonds seemed like beautiful ornaments, as those of a bride adorned with variegated golden fringes; and they were perfumed with the sweet savor of Christ, so that some supposed they had been anointed with earthly ointment.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:70
verses.text: But the others were downcast and humble and dejected and filled with every kind of disgrace, and they were reproached by the heathen as ignoble and weak, bearing the accusation of murderers, and having lost the one honorable and glorious and life-giving Name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:71
verses.text: The rest, beholding this, were strengthened, and when apprehended, they confessed without hesitation, paying no attention to the persuasions of the devil".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:72
verses.text: After certain other words they continue:  "After these things, finally, their martyrdoms were divided into every form.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:73
verses.text: For plaiting a crown of various colors and of all kinds of flowers, they presented it to the Father.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:74
verses.text: It was proper therefore that the noble athletes, having endured a manifold strife, and conquered grandly, should receive the crown, great and incorruptible.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:75
verses.text: "Maturus, therefore, and Sanctus and Blandina and Attalus were led to the amphitheater to be exposed to the wild beasts, and to give to the heathen public a spectacle of cruelty, a day for fighting with wild beasts being specially appointed on account of our people.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:76
verses.text: Both Maturus and Sanctus passed again through every torment in the amphitheater, as if they had suffered nothing before, or rather, as if, having already conquered their antagonist in many contests, they were now striving for the crown itself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:77
verses.text: They endured again the customary running of the gauntlet and the violence of the wild beasts, and everything which the furious people called for or desired, and at last, the iron chair in which their bodies being roasted, tormented them with the fumes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:78
verses.text: And not with this did the persecutors cease, but were yet more mad against them, determined to overcome their patience.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:79
verses.text: But even thus they did not hear a word from Sanctus except the confession which he had uttered from the beginning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:80
verses.text: These, then, after their life had continued for a long time through the great conflict, were at last sacrificed, having been made throughout that day a spectacle to the world, in place of the usual variety of combats.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:81
verses.text: "But Blandina was suspended on a stake, and exposed to be devoured by the wild beasts who should attack her.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:82
verses.text: And because she appeared as if hanging on a cross, and because of her earnest prayers, she inspired the combatants with great zeal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:83
verses.text: For they looked on her in her conflict, and beheld with their outward eyes, in the form of their sister, him who was crucified for them, that he might persuade those who believe on him, that every one who suffers for the glory of Christ has fellowship always with the living God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:84
verses.text: As none of the wild beasts at that time touched her, she was taken down from the stake, and cast again into prison.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:85
verses.text: She was preserved thus for another contest, that, being victorious in more conflicts, she might make the punishment of the crooked serpent irrevocable; and, though small and weak and despised, yet clothed with Christ the mighty and conquering Athlete, she might arouse the zeal of the brethren, and, having overcome the adversary many times might receive, through her conflict, the crown incorruptible.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:86
verses.text: "But Attalus was called for loudly by the people, because he was a person of distinction.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:87
verses.text: He entered the contest readily on account of a good conscience and his genuine practice in Christian discipline, and as he had always been a witness for the truth among us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:88
verses.text: He was led around the amphitheater, a tablet being carried before him on which was written in the Roman language 'This is Attalus the Christian,' and the people were filled with indignation against him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:89
verses.text: But when the governor learned that he was a Roman, he commanded him to be taken back with the rest of those who were in prison concerning whom he had written to Caesar, and whose answer he was awaiting.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:90
verses.text: "But the intervening time was not wasted nor fruitless to them; for by their patience the measureless compassion of Christ was manifested.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:91
verses.text: For through their continued life the dead were made alive, and the witnesses showed favor to those who had failed to witness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:92
verses.text: And the virgin mother had much joy in receiving alive those whom she had brought forth as dead.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:93
verses.text: For through their influence many who had denied were restored, and re-begotten, and rekindled with life, and learned to confess.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:94
verses.text: And being made alive and strengthened, they went to the judgment seat to be again interrogated by the governor; God, who desires not the death of the sinner, but mercifully invites to repentance, treating them with kindness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:95
verses.text: For Caesar commanded that they should be put to death, but that any who might deny should be set free.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:96
verses.text: Therefore, at the beginning of the public festival which took place there, and which was attended by crowds of men from all nations, the governor brought the blessed ones to the judgment seat, to make of them a show and spectacle for the multitude.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:97
verses.text: Wherefore also he examined them again, and beheaded those who appeared to possess Roman citizenship, but he sent the others to the wild beasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:98
verses.text: "And Christ was glorified greatly in those who had formerly denied him, for, contrary to the expectation of the heathen, they confessed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:99
verses.text: For they were examined by themselves, as about to be set free; but confessing, they were added to the order of the witnesses.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:100
verses.text: But some continued without, who had never possessed a trace of faith, nor any apprehension of the wedding garment, nor an understanding of the fear of God; but, as sons of perdition, they blasphemed the Way through their apostasy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:101
verses.text: But all the others were added to the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:102
verses.text: While these were being examined, a certain Alexander, a Phrygian by birth, and physician by profession, who had resided in Gaul for many years, and was well known to all on account of his love to God and boldness of speech (for he was not without a share of apostolic grace), standing before the judgment seat, and by signs encouraging them to confess, appeared to those standing by as if in travail.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:103
verses.text: But the people being enraged because those who formerly denied now confessed, cried out against Alexander as if he were the cause of this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:104
verses.text: Then the governor summoned him and inquired who he was.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:105
verses.text: And when he answered that he was a Christian, being very angry he condemned him to the wild beasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:106
verses.text: And on the next day he entered along with Attalus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:107
verses.text: For to please the people, the governor had ordered Attalus again to the wild beasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:108
verses.text: And they were tortured in the amphitheater with all the instruments contrived for that purpose, and having endured a very great conflict, were at last sacrificed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:109
verses.text: Alexander neither groaned nor murmured in any manner, but communed in his heart with God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:110
verses.text: But when Attalus was placed in the iron seat, and the fumes arose from his burning body, he said to the people in the Roman language: 'Lo! this which ye do is devouring men; but we do not devour men; nor do any other wicked thing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:111
verses.text: ' And being asked, what name God has, he replied, 'God has not a name as man has.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:113
verses.text: "After all these, on the last day of the contests, Blandina was again brought in, with Ponticus, a boy about fifteen years old.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:114
verses.text: They had been brought every day to witness the sufferings of the others, and had been pressed to swear by the idols.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:115
verses.text: But because they remained steadfast and despised them, the multitude became furious, so that they had no compassion for the youth of the boy nor respect for the sex of the woman.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:116
verses.text: Therefore they exposed them to all the terrible sufferings and took them through the entire round of torture, repeatedly urging them to swear, but being unable to effect this; for Ponticus, encouraged by his sister so that even the heathen could see that she was confirming and strengthening him, having nobly endured every torture, gave up the ghost.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:117
verses.text: But the blessed Blandina, last of all, having, as a noble mother, encouraged her children and sent them before her victorious to the King, endured herself all their conflicts and hastened after them, glad and rejoicing in her departure as if called to a marriage supper, rather than cast to wild beasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:118
verses.text: And, after the scourging, after the wild beasts, after the roasting seat, she was finally enclosed in a net, and thrown before a bull.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:119
verses.text: And having been tossed about by the animal, but feeling none of the things which were happening to her, on account of her hope and firm hold upon what had been entrusted to her, and her communion with Christ, she also was sacrificed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:120
verses.text: And the heathen themselves confessed that never among them had a woman endured so many and such terrible tortures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:121
verses.text: "But not even thus was their madness and cruelty toward the saints satisfied.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:122
verses.text: For, incited by the Wild Beast, wild and barbarous tribes were not easily appeased, and their violence found another peculiar opportunity in the dead bodies.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:123
verses.text: For, through their lack of manly reason, the fact that they had been conquered did not put them to shame, but rather the more enkindled their wrath as that of a wild beast, and aroused alike the hatred of governor and people to treat us unjustly; that the Scripture might be fulfilled: 'He that is lawless, let him be lawless still, and he that is righteous, let him be righteous still.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:125
verses.text: For they cast to the dogs those who had died of suffocation in the prison, carefully guarding them by night and day, lest any one should be buried by us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:126
verses.text: And they exposed the remains left by the wild beasts and by fire, mangled and charred, and placed the heads of the others by their bodies, and guarded them in like manner from burial by a watch of soldiers for many days.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:127
verses.text: And some raged and gnashed their teeth against them, desiring to execute more severe vengeance upon them; but others laughed and mocked at them, magnifying their own idols, and imputed to them the punishment of the Christians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:128
verses.text: Even the more reasonable, and those who had seemed to sympathize somewhat, reproached them often, saying, 'Where is their God, and what has their religion, which they have chosen rather than life, profited them?'.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:129
verses.text: So various was their conduct toward us; but we were in deep affliction because we could not bury the bodies.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:130
verses.text: For neither did night avail us for this purpose, nor did money persuade, nor entreaty move to compassion; but they kept watch in every way, as if the prevention of the burial would be of some great advantage to them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:131
verses.text: In addition, they say after other things:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:132
verses.text: "The bodies of the martyrs, having thus in every manner been exhibited and exposed for six days, were afterward burned and reduced to ashes, and swept into the Rhone by the wicked men, so that no trace of them might appear on the earth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:133
verses.text: And this they did, as if able to conquer God, and prevent their new birth; 'that,' as they said, 'they may have no hope of a resurrection, through trust in which they bring to us this foreign and new religion, and despise terrible things, and are ready even to go to death with joy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 2:134
verses.text: Now let us see if they will rise again, and if their God is able to help them, and to deliver them out of our hands.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:2
verses.text: â€”The Martyrs, beloved of God, kindly ministered unto those who fell in the Persecution.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:3
verses.text: Such things happened to the churches of Christ under the above-mentioned emperor, from which we may reasonably conjecture the occurrences in the other provinces.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:4
verses.text: It is proper to add other selections from the same letter, in which the moderation and compassion of these witnesses is recorded in the following words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:5
verses.text: "They were also so zealous in their imitation of Christ,â€”'who, being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God,'â€”that, though they had attained such honor, and had borne witness, not once or twice, but many times,â€”having been brought back to prison from the wild beasts, covered with burns and scars and wounds,â€”yet they did not proclaim themselves witnesses, nor did they suffer us to address them by this name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:6
verses.text: If any one of us, in letter or conversation, spoke of them as witnesses, they rebuked him sharply.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:7
verses.text: For they conceded cheerfully the appellation of Witness to Christ 'the faithful and true Witness,' and 'firstborn of the dead,' and prince of the life of God; and they reminded us of the witnesses who had already departed, and said, 'They are already witnesses whom Christ has deemed worthy to be taken up in their confession, having sealed their testimony by their departure; but we are lowly and humble confessors.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:8
verses.text: ' And they besought the brethren with tears that earnest prayers should be offered that they might be made perfect.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:9
verses.text: They showed in their deeds the power of 'testimony,' manifesting great boldness toward all the brethren, and they made plain their nobility through patience and fearlessness and courage, but they refused the title of Witnesses as distinguishing them from their brethren, being filled with the fear of God".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:10
verses.text: A little further on they say: "They humbled themselves under the mighty hand, by which they are now greatly exalted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:11
verses.text: They defended all, but accused none.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:12
verses.text: They absolved all, but bound none.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:13
verses.text: And they prayed for those who had inflicted cruelties upon them, even as Stephen, the perfect witness, 'Lord, lay not this sin to their charge.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:14
verses.text: ' But if he prayed for those who stoned him, how much more for the brethren!".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:15
verses.text: And again after mentioning other matters, they say:  "For, through the genuineness of their love, their greatest contest with him was that the Beast, being choked, might cast out alive those whom he supposed he had swallowed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:16
verses.text: For they did not boast over the fallen, but helped them in their need with those things in which they themselves abounded, having the compassion of a mother, and shedding many tears on their account before the Father.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:17
verses.text: They asked for life, and he gave it to them, and they shared it with their neighbors.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:18
verses.text: Victorious over everything, they departed to God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:19
verses.text: Having always loved peace, and having commended peace to us they went in peace to God, leaving no sorrow to their mother, nor division or strife to the brethren, but joy and peace and concord and love".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 3:20
verses.text: This record of the affection of those blessed ones toward the brethren that had fallen may be profitably added on account of the inhuman and unmerciful disposition of those who, after these events, acted unsparingly toward the members of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:2
verses.text: â€”The Vision which appeared in a Dream to the Witness Attalus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:3
verses.text: The same letter of the above-mentioned witnesses contains another account worthy of remembrance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:4
verses.text: No one will object to our bringing it to the knowledge of our readers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:5
verses.text: It runs as follows: "For a certain Alcibiades, who was one of them, led a very austere life, partaking of nothing whatever but bread and water.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:6
verses.text: When he endeavored to continue this same sort of life in prison, it was revealed to Attalus after his first conflict in the amphitheater that Alcibiades was not doing well in refusing the creatures of God and placing a stumbling-block before others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:7
verses.text: And Alcibiades obeyed, and partook of all things without restraint, giving thanks to God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:8
verses.text: For they were not deprived of the grace of God, but the Holy Ghost was their counselor".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:9
verses.text: Let this suffice for these matters.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:10
verses.text: The followers of Montanus, Alcibiades and Theodotus in Phrygia were now first giving wide circulation to their assumption in regard to prophecy,â€”for the many other miracles that, through the gift of God, were still wrought in the different churches caused their prophesying to be readily credited by many,â€”and as dissension arose concerning them, the brethren in Gaul set forth their own prudent and most orthodox judgment in the matter, and published also several epistles from the witnesses that had been put to death among them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 4:11
verses.text: These they sent, while they were still in prison, to the brethren throughout Asia and Phrygia, and also to Eleutherus, who was then bishop of Rome, negotiating for the peace of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:2
verses.text: â€”Irenaeus commended by the Witnesses in a Letter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:3
verses.text: The same witnesses also recommended Irenaeus, who was already at that time a presbyter of the parish of Lyons, to the above-mentioned bishop of Rome, saying many favorable things in regard to him, as the following extract shows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:4
verses.text: "We pray, father Eleutherus, that you may rejoice in God in all things and always.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:5
verses.text: We have requested our brother and comrade Irenaeus to carry this letter to you, and we ask you to hold him in esteem, as zealous for the covenant of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:6
verses.text: For if we thought that office could confer righteousness upon any one, we should commend him among the first as a presbyter of the church, which is his position".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:7
verses.text: Why should we transcribe the catalogue of the witnesses given in the letter already mentioned, of whom some were beheaded, others cast to the wild beasts, and others fell asleep in prison, or give the number of confessors still surviving at that time? For whoever desires can readily find the full account by consulting the letter itself, which, as I have said, is recorded in our Collection of Martyrdoms.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 5:8
verses.text: Such were the events which happened under Antoninus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:2
verses.text: â€”God sent Rain from Heaven for Marcus Aurelius Caesar in Answer to the Prayers of our People.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:3
verses.text: It is reported that Marcus Aurelius Caesar, brother of Antoninus, being about to engage in battle with the Germans and Sarmatians, was in great trouble on account of his army suffering from thirst.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:4
verses.text: But the soldiers of the so-called Melitene legion, through the faith which has given strength from that time to the present, when they were drawn up before the enemy, kneeled on the ground, as is our custom in prayer, and engaged in supplications to God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:5
verses.text: This was indeed a strange sight to the enemy, but it is reported that a stranger thing immediately followed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:6
verses.text: The lightning drove the enemy to flight and destruction, but a shower refreshed the army of those who had called on God, all of whom had been on the point of perishing with thirst.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:7
verses.text: This story is related by non-Christian writers who have been pleased to treat the times referred to, and it has also been recorded by our own people.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:8
verses.text: By those historians who were strangers to the faith, the marvel is mentioned, but it is not acknowledged as an answer to our prayers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:9
verses.text: But by our own people, as friends of the truth, the occurrence is related in a simple and artless manner.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:10
verses.text: Among these is Apolinarius, who says that from that time the legion through whose prayers the wonder took place received from the emperor a title appropriate to the event, being called in the language of the Romans the Thundering Legion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:11
verses.text: Tertullian is a trustworthy witness of these things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:12
verses.text: In the Apology for the Faith, which he addressed to the Roman Senate, and which work we have already mentioned, he confirms the history with greater and stronger proofs.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:13
verses.text: He writes that there are still extant letters of the most intelligent Emperor Marcus in which he testifies that his army, being on the point of perishing with thirst in Germany, was saved by the prayers of the Christians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:14
verses.text: And he says also that this emperor threatened death to those who brought accusation against us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:15
verses.text: He adds further:  "What kind of laws are those which impious, unjust, and cruel persons use against us alone? which Vespasian, though he had conquered the Jews, did not regard; which Trajan partially annulled, forbidding Christians to be sought after; which neither Adrian, though inquisitive in all matters, nor he who was called Pius sanctioned".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:16
verses.text: But let any one treat these things as he chooses; we must pass on to what followed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:17
verses.text: Pothinus having died with the other martyrs in Gaul at ninety years of age, Irenaeus succeeded him in the episcopate of the church at Lyons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:18
verses.text: We have learned that, in his youth, he was a hearer of Polycarp.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:19
verses.text: In the third book of his work Against Heresies he has inserted a list of the bishops of Rome, bringing it down as far as Eleutherus (whose times we are now considering), under whom he composed his work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 6:20
verses.text: He writes as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:2
verses.text: â€”Catalogue of the Bishops of Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:3
verses.text: "The blessed apostles having founded and established the church, entrusted the office of the episcopate to Linus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:4
verses.text: Paul speaks of this Linus in his Epistles to Timothy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:5
verses.text: Anencletus succeeded him, and after Anencletus, in the third place from the apostles, Clement received the episcopate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:6
verses.text: He had seen and conversed with the blessed apostles, and their preaching was still sounding in his ears, and their tradition was still before his eyes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:7
verses.text: Nor was he alone in this, for many who had been taught by the apostles yet survived.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:8
verses.text: In the times of Clement, a serious dissension having arisen among the brethren in Corinth, the church of Rome sent a most suitable letter to the Corinthians, reconciling them in peace, renewing their faith, and proclaiming the doctrine lately received from the apostles".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:9
verses.text: A little farther on he says:  "Evarestus succeeded Clement, and Alexander, Evarestus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:10
verses.text: Then Xystus, the sixth from the apostles, was appointed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:11
verses.text: After him Telesphorus, who suffered martyrdom gloriously; then Hyginus; then Pius; and after him Anicetus; Soter succeeded Anicetus; and now, in the twelfth place from the apostles, Eleutherus holds the office of bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 7:12
verses.text: In the same order and succession the tradition in the Church and the preaching of the truth has descended from the apostles unto us".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:2
verses.text: â€”Even down to those Times Miracles were performed by the Faithful.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:3
verses.text: These things Irenaeus, in agreement with the accounts already given by us, records in the work which comprises five books, and to which he gave the title Refutation and Overthrow of the Knowledge Falsely So-called.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:4
verses.text: In the second book of the same treatise he shows that manifestations of divine and miraculous power continued to his time in some of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:5
verses.text: He says:  "But so far do they come short of raising the dead, as the Lord raised them, and the apostles through prayer.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:6
verses.text: And oftentimes in the brotherhood, when, on account of some necessity, our entire Church has besought with fasting and much supplication, the spirit of the dead has returned, and the man has been restored through the prayers of the saints".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:7
verses.text: And again, after other remarks, he says:  "If they will say that even the Lord did these things in mere appearance, we will refer them to the prophetic writings, and show from them that all things were beforehand spoken of him in this manner, and were strictly fulfilled; and that he alone is the Son of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:8
verses.text: Wherefore his true disciples, receiving grace from him, perform such works in his Name for the benefit of other men, as each has received the gift from him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:9
verses.text: For some of them drive out demons effectually and truly, so that those who have been cleansed from evil spirits frequently believe and unite with the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:10
verses.text: Others have a foreknowledge of future events, and visions, and prophetic revelations.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:11
verses.text: Still others heal the sick by the laying on of hands, and restore them to health.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:12
verses.text: And, as we have said, even dead persons have been raised, and remained with us many years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:13
verses.text: But why should we say more? It is not possible to recount the number of gifts which the Church, throughout all the world, has received from God in the name of Jesus Christ, who was crucified under Pontius Pilate, and exercises every day for the benefit of the heathen, never deceiving any nor doing it for money.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:14
verses.text: For as she has received freely from God, freely also does she minister".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:15
verses.text: And in another place the same author writes:  "As also we hear that many brethren in the Church possess prophetic gifts, and speak, through the Spirit, with all kinds of tongues, and bring to light the secret things of men for their good, and declare the mysteries of God".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 8:16
verses.text: So much in regard to the fact that various gifts remained among those who were worthy even until that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:2
verses.text: â€”The Statements of Irenaeus in regard to the Divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:3
verses.text: Since, in the beginning of this work, we promised to give, when needful, the words of the ancient presbyters and writers of the Church, in which they have declared those traditions which came down to them concerning the canonical books, and since Irenaeus was one of them, we will now give his words and, first, what he says of the sacred Gospels:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:4
verses.text: "Matthew published his Gospel among the Hebrews in their own language, while Peter and Paul were preaching and founding the church in Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:5
verses.text: After their departure Mark, the disciple and interpreter of Peter, also transmitted to us in writing those things which Peter had preached; and Luke, the attendant of Paul, recorded in a book the Gospel which Paul had declared.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:6
verses.text: Afterwards John, the disciple of the Lord, who also reclined on his bosom, published his Gospel, while staying at Ephesus in Asia".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:7
verses.text: He states these things in the third book of his above-mentioned work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:8
verses.text: In the fifth book he speaks as follows concerning the Apocalypse of John, and the number of the name of Antichrist:  "As these things are so, and this number is found in all the approved and ancient copies, and those who saw John face to face confirm it, and reason teaches us that the number of the name of the beast, according to the mode of calculation among the Greeks, appears in its letters.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:10
verses.text: And farther on he says concerning the same:  "We are not bold enough to speak confidently of the name of Antichrist.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:11
verses.text: For if it were necessary that his name should be declared clearly at the present time, it would have been announced by him who saw the revelation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:12
verses.text: For it was seen, not long ago, but almost in our generation, toward the end of the reign of Domitian".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:13
verses.text: He states these things concerning the Apocalypse in the work referred to.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:14
verses.text: He also mentions the first Epistle of John, taking many proofs from it, and likewise the first Epistle of Peter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:15
verses.text: And he not only knows, but also receives, The Shepherd, writing as follows:  "Well did the Scripture speak, saying, 'First of all believe that God is one, who has created and completed all things,'" &c.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:16
verses.text: And he uses almost the precise words of the Wisdom of Solomon, saying: "The vision of God produces immortality, but immortality renders us near to God".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:17
verses.text: He mentions also the memoirs of a certain apostolic presbyter, whose name he passes by in silence, and gives his expositions of the sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:18
verses.text: And he refers to Justin the Martyr, and to Ignatius, using testimonies also from their writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:19
verses.text: Moreover, he promises to refute Marcion from his own writings, in a special work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:20
verses.text: Concerning the translation of the inspired Scriptures by the Seventy, hear the very words which he writes:  "God in truth became man, and the Lord himself saved us, giving the sign of the virgin; but not as some say, who now venture to translate the Scripture, 'Behold, a young woman shall conceive and bring forth a son,' as Theodotion of Ephesus and Aquila of Pontus, both of them Jewish proselytes, interpreted; following whom, the Ebionites say that he was begotten by Joseph".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:21
verses.text: Shortly after he adds:  "For before the Romans had established their empire, while the Macedonians were still holding Asia, Ptolemy, the son of Lagus, being desirous of adorning the library which he had founded in Alexandria with the meritorious writings of all men, requested the people of Jerusalem to have their Scriptures translated into the Greek language.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:22
verses.text: But, as they were then subject to the Macedonians, they sent to Ptolemy seventy elders, who were the most skilled among them in the Scriptures and in both languages.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:23
verses.text: Thus God accomplished his purpose.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:24
verses.text: But wishing to try them individually, as he feared lest, by taking counsel together, they might conceal the truth of the Scriptures by their interpretation, he separated them from one another, and commanded all of them to write the same translation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:25
verses.text: He did this for all the books.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:26
verses.text: But when they came together in the presence of Ptolemy, and compared their several translations, God was glorified, and the Scriptures were recognized as truly divine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:27
verses.text: For all of them had rendered the same things in the same words and with the same names from beginning to end, so that the heathen perceived that the Scriptures had been translated by the inspiration of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:28
verses.text: And this was nothing wonderful for God to do, who, in the captivity of the people under Nebuchadnezzar, when the Scriptures had been destroyed, and the Jews had returned to their own country after seventy years, afterwards, in the time of Artaxerxes, king of the Persians, inspired Ezra the priest, of the tribe of Levi, to relate all the words of the former prophets, and to restore to the people the legislation of Moses".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 9:29
verses.text: Such are the words of Irenaeus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 10:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 10:2
verses.text: â€”The Bishops under Commodus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 10:3
verses.text: After Antoninus had been emperor for nineteen years, Commodus received the government.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 10:4
verses.text: In his first year Julian became bishop of the Alexandrian churches, after Agrippinus had held the office for twelve years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:2
verses.text: â€”Pantaenus the Philosopher.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:3
verses.text: About that time, Pantaenus, a man highly distinguished for his learning, had charge of the school of the faithful in Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:4
verses.text: A school of sacred learning, which continues to our day, was established there in ancient times, and as we have been informed, was managed by men of great ability and zeal for divine things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:5
verses.text: Among these it is reported that Pantaenus was at that time especially conspicuous, as he had been educated in the philosophical system of those called Stoics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:6
verses.text: They say that he displayed such zeal for the divine Word, that he was appointed as a herald of the Gospel of Christ to the nations in the East, and was sent as far as India.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:7
verses.text: For indeed there were still many evangelists of the Word who sought earnestly to use their inspired zeal, after the examples of the apostles, for the increase and building up of the Divine Word.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:8
verses.text: Pantaenus was one of these, and is said to have gone to India.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:9
verses.text: It is reported that among persons there who knew of Christ, he found the Gospel according to Matthew, which had anticipated his own arrival.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:10
verses.text: For Bartholomew, one of the apostles, had preached to them, and left with them the writing of Matthew in the Hebrew language, which they had preserved till that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 11:11
verses.text: After many good deeds, Pantaenus finally became the head of the school at Alexandria, and expounded the treasures of divine doctrine both orally and in writing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:2
verses.text: â€”Clement of Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:3
verses.text: At this time Clement, being trained with him in the divine Scriptures at Alexandria, became well known.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:4
verses.text: He had the same name as the one who anciently was at the head of the Roman church, and who was a disciple of the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:5
verses.text: In his Hypotyposes he speaks of Pantaenus by name as his teacher.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:6
verses.text: It seems to me that he alludes to the same person also in the first book of his Stromata, when, referring to the more conspicuous of the successors of the apostles whom he had met, he says:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:7
verses.text: "This work is not a writing artfully constructed for display; but my notes are stored up for old age, as a remedy against forgetfulness; an image without art, and a rough sketch of those powerful and animated words which it was my privilege to hear, as well as of blessed and truly remarkable men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:8
verses.text: Of these the oneâ€”the Ionianâ€”was in Greece, the other in Magna Graecia; the one of them was from Coele-Syria, the other from Egypt.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:9
verses.text: There were others in the East, one of them an Assyrian, the other a Hebrew in Palestine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:10
verses.text: But when I met with the last,â€”in ability truly he was first,â€”having hunted him out in his concealment in Egypt, I found rest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 12:11
verses.text: These men, preserving the true tradition of the blessed doctrine, directly from the holy apostles, Peter and James and John and Paul, the son receiving it from the father (but few were like the fathers), have come by God's will even to us to deposit those ancestral and apostolic seeds".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:2
verses.text: â€”The Bishops in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:3
verses.text: At this time Narcissus was the bishop of the church at Jerusalem, and he is celebrated by many to this day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:4
verses.text: He was the fifteenth in succession from the siege of the Jews under Adrian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:5
verses.text: We have shown that from that time first the church in Jerusalem was composed of Gentiles, after those of the circumcision, and that Marcus was the first Gentile bishop that presided over them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 13:6
verses.text: After him the succession in the episcopate was: first Cassianus; after him Publius; then Maximus; following them Julian; then Gaius; after him Symmachus and another Gaius, and again another Julian; after these Capito and Valens and Dolichianus; and after all of them Narcissus, the thirtieth in regular succession from the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:2
verses.text: â€”Rhodo and his Account of the Dissension of Marcion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:3
verses.text: At this time Rhodo, a native of Asia, who had been instructed, as he himself states, by Tatian, with whom we have already become acquainted, having written several books, published among the rest one against the heresy of Marcion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:4
verses.text: He says that this heresy was divided in his time into various opinions; and while describing those who occasioned the division, he refutes accurately the falsehoods devised by each of them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:5
verses.text: But hear what he writes:  "Therefore also they disagree among themselves, maintaining an inconsistent opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:6
verses.text: For Apelles, one of the herd, priding himself on his manner of life and his age, acknowledges one principle, but says that the prophecies are from an opposing spirit, being led to this view by the responses of a maiden by name Philumene, who was possessed by a demon.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:7
verses.text: But others, among whom are Potitus and Basilicus, hold to two principles, as does the mariner Marcion himself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:8
verses.text: These following the wolf of Pontus, and, like him, unable to fathom the division of things, became reckless, and without giving any proof asserted two principles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:9
verses.text: Others, again, drifting into a worse error, consider that there are not only two, but three natures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:10
verses.text: Of these, Syneros is the leader and chief, as those who defend his teaching say".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:11
verses.text: The same author writes that he engaged in conversation with Apelles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:12
verses.text: He speaks as follows:  "For the old man Apelles, when conversing with us, was refuted in many things which he spoke falsely; whence also he said that it was not at all necessary to examine one's doctrine, but that each one should continue to hold what he believed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:13
verses.text: For he asserted that those who trusted in the Crucified would be saved, if only they were found doing good works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:14
verses.text: But as we have said before, his opinion concerning God was the most obscure of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:15
verses.text: For he spoke of one principle, as also our doctrine does".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:16
verses.text: Then, after stating fully his own opinion, he adds:  "When I said to him, Tell me how you know this or how can you assert that there is one principle, he replied that the prophecies refuted themselves, because they have said nothing true; for they are inconsistent, and false, and self-contradictory.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:17
verses.text: But how there is one principle he said that he did not know, but that he was thus persuaded.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:18
verses.text: As I then adjured him to speak the truth, he swore that he did so when he said that he did not know how there is one unbegotten God, but that he believed it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:19
verses.text: Thereupon I laughed and reproved him because, though calling himself a teacher, he knew not how to confirm what he taught".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:20
verses.text: In the same work, addressing Callistio, the same writer acknowledges that he had been instructed at Rome by Tatian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:21
verses.text: And he says that a book of Problems had been prepared by Tatian, in which he promised to explain the obscure and hidden parts of the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:22
verses.text: Rhodo himself promises to give in a work of his own solutions of Tatian's problems.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:23
verses.text: There is also extant a Commentary of his on the Hexaemeron.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:24
verses.text: But this Apelles wrote many things, in an impious manner, of the law of Moses, blaspheming the divine words in many of his works, being, as it seemed, very zealous for their refutation and overthrow.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 14:25
verses.text: So much concerning these.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 15:2
verses.text: â€”The False Prophets of the Phrygians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 15:3
verses.text: The enemy of God's Church, who is emphatically a hater of good and a lover of evil, and leaves untried no manner of craft against men, was again active in causing strange heresies to spring up against the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 15:4
verses.text: For some persons, like venomous reptiles, crawled over Asia and Phrygia, boasting that Montanus was the Paraclete, and that the women that followed him, Priscilla and Maximilla, were prophetesses of Montanus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 16:2
verses.text: â€”The Schism of Blastus at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 16:3
verses.text: Others, of whom Florinus was chief, flourished at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 16:4
verses.text: He fell from the presbyterate of the Church, and Blastus was involved in a similar fall.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 16:5
verses.text: They also drew away many of the Church to their opinion, each striving to introduce his own innovations in respect to the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:2
verses.text: â€”The Circumstances related of Montanus and his False Prophets.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:3
verses.text: Against the so-called Phrygian heresy, the power which always contends for the truth raised up a strong and invincible weapon, Apolinarius of Hierapolis, whom we have mentioned before, and with him many other men of ability, by whom abundant material for our history has been left.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:4
verses.text: A certain one of these, in the beginning of his work against them, first intimates that he had contended with them in oral controversies.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:5
verses.text: He commences his work in this manner:  "Having for a very long and sufficient time, O beloved Avircius Marcellus, been urged by you to write a treatise against the heresy of those who are called after Miltiades, I have hesitated till the present time, not through lack of ability to refute the falsehood or bear testimony for the truth, but from fear and apprehension that I might seem to some to be making additions to the doctrines or precepts of the Gospel of the New Testament, which it is impossible for one who has chosen to live according to the Gospel, either to increase or to diminish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:6
verses.text: But being recently in Ancyra in Galatia, I found the church there greatly agitated by this novelty, not prophecy, as they call it, but rather false prophecy, as will be shown.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:7
verses.text: Therefore, to the best of our ability, with the Lord's help, we disputed in the church many days concerning these and other matters separately brought forward by them, so that the church rejoiced and was strengthened in the truth, and those of the opposite side were for the time confounded, and the adversaries were grieved.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:8
verses.text: The presbyters in the place, our fellow-presbyter Zoticus of Otrous also being present, requested us to leave a record of what had been said against the opposers of the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:9
verses.text: We did not do this, but we promised to write it out as soon as the Lord permitted us, and to send it to them speedily".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:10
verses.text: Having said this with other things, in the beginning of his work, he proceeds to state the cause of the above-mentioned heresy as follows:  "Their opposition and their recent heresy which has separated them from the Church arose on the following account.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:11
verses.text: There is said to be a certain village called Ardabau in that part of Mysia, which borders upon Phrygia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:12
verses.text: There first, they say, when Gratus was proconsul of Asia, a recent convert, Montanus by name, through his unquenchable desire for leadership, gave the adversary opportunity against him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:13
verses.text: And he became beside himself, and being suddenly in a sort of frenzy and ecstasy, he raved, and began to babble and utter strange things, prophesying in a manner contrary to the constant custom of the Church handed down by tradition from the beginning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:14
verses.text: Some of those who heard his spurious utterances at that time were indignant, and they rebuked him as one that was possessed, and that was under the control of a demon, and was led by a deceitful spirit, and was distracting the multitude; and they forbade him to talk, remembering the distinction drawn by the Lord and his warning to guard watchfully against the coming of false prophets.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:15
verses.text: But others imagining themselves possessed of the Holy Spirit and of a prophetic gift, were elated and not a little puffed up; and forgetting the distinction of the Lord, they challenged the mad and insidious and seducing spirit, and were cheated and deceived by him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:16
verses.text: In consequence of this, he could no longer be held in check, so as to keep silence.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:17
verses.text: Thus by artifice, or rather by such a system of wicked craft, the devil, devising destruction for the disobedient, and being unworthily honored by them, secretly excited and inflamed their understandings which had already become estranged from the true faith.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:18
verses.text: And he stirred up besides two women, and filled them with the false spirit, so that they talked wildly and unreasonably and strangely, like the person already mentioned.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:19
verses.text: And the spirit pronounced them blessed as they rejoiced and gloried in him, and puffed them up by the magnitude of his promises.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:20
verses.text: But sometimes he rebuked them openly in a wise and faithful manner, that he might seem to be a reprover.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:21
verses.text: But those of the Phrygians that were deceived were few in number.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:22
verses.text: "And the arrogant spirit taught them to revile the entire universal Church under heaven, because the spirit of false prophecy received neither honor from it nor entrance into it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:23
verses.text: For the faithful in Asia met often in many places throughout Asia to consider this matter, and examined the novel utterances and pronounced them profane, and rejected the heresy, and thus these persons were expelled from the Church and debarred from communion".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:24
verses.text: Having related these things at the outset, and continued the refutation of their delusion through his entire work, in the second book he speaks as follows of their end:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:25
verses.text: "Since, therefore, they called us slayers of the prophets because we did not receive their loquacious prophets, who, they say, are those that the Lord promised to send to the people, let them answer as in God's presence: Who is there, O friends, of these who began to talk, from Montanus and the women down, that was persecuted by the Jews, or slain by lawless men? None.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:26
verses.text: Or has any of them been seized and crucified for the Name? Truly not.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:27
verses.text: Or has one of these women ever been scourged in the synagogues of the Jews, or stoned? No; never anywhere.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:28
verses.text: But by another kind of death Montanus and Maximilla are said to have died.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:29
verses.text: For the report is that, incited by the spirit of frenzy, they both hung themselves; not at the same time, but at the time which common report gives for the death of each.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:30
verses.text: And thus they died, and ended their lives like the traitor Judas.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:31
verses.text: So also, as general report says, that remarkable person, the first steward, as it were, of their so-called prophecy, one Theodotusâ€”who, as if at sometime taken up and received into heaven, fell into trances, and entrusted himself to the deceitful spiritâ€”was pitched like a quoit, and died miserably.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:32
verses.text: They say that these things happened in this manner.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:33
verses.text: But as we did not see them, O friend, we do not pretend to know.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:34
verses.text: Perhaps in such a manner, perhaps not, Montanus and Theodotus and the above-mentioned woman died".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:35
verses.text: He says again in the same book that the holy bishops of that time attempted to refute the spirit in Maximilla, but were prevented by others who plainly co-operated with the spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:36
verses.text: He writes as follows:  "And let not the spirit, in the same work of Asterius Urbanus, say through Maximilla, 'I am driven away from the sheep like a wolf.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:37
verses.text: I am not a wolf.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:38
