verses.text: I am word and spirit and power.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:39
verses.text: ' But let him show clearly and prove the power in the spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:40
verses.text: And by the spirit let him compel those to confess him who were then present for the purpose of proving and reasoning with the talkative spirit,â€”those eminent men and bishops, Zoticus, from the village Comana, and Julian, from Apamea, whose mouths the followers of Themiso muzzled, refusing to permit the false and seductive spirit to be refuted by them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:41
verses.text: Again in the same work, after saying other things in refutation of the false prophecies of Maximilla, he indicates the time when he wrote these accounts, and mentions her predictions in which she prophesied wars and anarchy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:42
verses.text: Their falsehood he censures in the following manner:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:43
verses.text: "And has not this been shown clearly to be false? For it is to-day more than thirteen years since the woman died, and there has been neither a partial nor general war in the world; but rather, through the mercy of God, continued peace even to the Christians".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:44
verses.text: These things are taken from the second book.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:45
verses.text: I will add also short extracts from the third book, in which he speaks thus against their boasts that many of them had suffered martyrdom:  "When therefore they are at a loss, being refuted in all that they say, they try to take refuge in their martyrs, alleging that they have many martyrs, and that this is sure evidence of the power of the so-called prophetic spirit that is with them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:46
verses.text: But this, as it appears, is entirely fallacious.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:47
verses.text: For some of the heresies have a great many martyrs; but surely we shall not on that account agree with them or confess that they hold the truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:48
verses.text: And first, indeed, those called Marcionites, from the heresy of Marcion, say that they have a multitude of martyrs for Christ; yet they do not confess Christ himself in truth".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:49
verses.text: A little farther on he continues:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:50
verses.text: "When those called to martyrdom from the Church for the truth of the faith have met with any of the so-called martyrs of the Phrygian heresy, they have separated from them, and died without any fellowship with them, because they did not wish to give their assent to the spirit of Montanus and the women.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 17:51
verses.text: And that this is true and took place in our own time in Apamea on the Maeander, among those who suffered martyrdom with Gaius and Alexander of Eumenia, is well known".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:2
verses.text: â€”Miltiades and His Works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:3
verses.text: In this work he mentions a writer, Miltiades, stating that he also wrote a certain book against the above-mentioned heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:4
verses.text: After quoting some of their words, he adds:  "Having found these things in a certain work of theirs in opposition to the work of the brother Alcibiades, in which he shows that a prophet ought not to speak in ecstasy, I made an abridgment".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:5
verses.text: A little further on in the same work he gives a list of those who prophesied under the new covenant, among whom he enumerates a certain Ammia and Quadratus, saying:  "But the false prophet falls into an ecstasy, in which he is without shame or fear.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:6
verses.text: Beginning with purposed ignorance, he passes on, as has been stated, to involuntary madness of soul.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:7
verses.text: They cannot show that one of the old or one of the new prophets was thus carried away in spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:8
verses.text: Neither can they boast of Agabus, or Judas, or Silas, or the daughters of Philip, or Ammia in Philadelphia, or Quadratus, or any others not belonging to them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:9
verses.text: And again after a little he says: "For if after Quadratus and Ammia in Philadelphia, as they assert, the women with Montanus received the prophetic gift, let them show who among them received it from Montanus and the women.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:10
verses.text: For the apostle thought it necessary that the prophetic gift should continue in all the Church until the final coming.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:11
verses.text: But they cannot show it, though this is the fourteenth year since the death of Maximilla".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:12
verses.text: He writes thus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:13
verses.text: But the Miltiades to whom he refers has left other monuments of his own zeal for the Divine Scriptures, in the discourses which he composed against the Greeks and against the Jews, answering each of them separately in two books.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 18:14
verses.text: And in addition he addresses an apology to the earthly rulers, in behalf of the philosophy which he embraced.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:2
verses.text: â€”The Manner in which Apollonius refuted the Phrygians, and the Personswhom he Mentions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:3
verses.text: As the so-called Phrygian heresy was still flourishing in Phrygia in his time, Apollonius also, an ecclesiastical writer, undertook its refutation, and wrote a special work against it, correcting in detail the false prophecies current among them and reproving the life of the founders of the heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:4
verses.text: But hear his own words respecting Montanus:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:5
verses.text: "His actions and his teaching show who this new teacher is.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:6
verses.text: This is he who taught the dissolution of marriage; who made laws for fasting; who named Pepuza and Tymion, small towns in Phrygia, Jerusalem, wishing to gather people to them from all directions; who appointed collectors of money; who contrived the receiving of gifts under the name of offerings; who provided salaries for those who preached his doctrine, that its teaching might prevail through gluttony".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:7
verses.text: He writes thus concerning Montanus; and a little farther on he writes as follows concerning his prophetesses: "We show that these first prophetesses themselves, as soon as they were filled with the Spirit, abandoned their husbands.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:8
verses.text: How falsely therefore they speak who call Prisca a virgin".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:9
verses.text: Afterwards he says: "Does not all Scripture seem to you to forbid a prophet to receive gifts and money? When therefore I see the prophetess receiving gold and silver and costly garments, how can I avoid reproving her?".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:10
verses.text: And again a little farther on he speaks thus concerning one of their confessors:  "So also Themiso, who was clothed with plausible covetousness, could not endure the sign of confession, but threw aside bonds for an abundance of possessions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:11
verses.text: Yet, though he should have been humble on this account, he dared to boast as a martyr, and in imitation of the apostle, he wrote a certain catholic epistle, to instruct those whose faith was better than his own, contending for words of empty sound, and blaspheming against the Lord and the apostles and the holy Church".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:12
verses.text: And again concerning others of those honored among them as martyrs, he writes as follows:  "Not to speak of many, let the prophetess herself tell us of Alexander, who called himself a martyr, with whom she is in the habit of banqueting, and who is worshiped by many.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:13
verses.text: We need not mention his robberies and other daring deeds for which he was punished, but the archives contain them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:14
verses.text: Which of these forgives the sins of the other? Does the prophet the robberies of the martyr, or the martyr the covetousness of the prophet? For although the Lord said, 'Provide neither gold, nor silver, neither two coats,' these men, in complete opposition, transgress in respect to the possession of the forbidden things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:15
verses.text: For we will show that those whom they call prophets and martyrs gather their gain not only from rich men, but also from the poor, and orphans, and widows.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:16
verses.text: But if they are confident, let them stand up and discuss these matters, that if convicted they may hereafter cease transgressing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:17
verses.text: For the fruits of the prophet must be tried; 'for the tree is known by its fruit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:19
verses.text: But that those who wish may know concerning Alexander, he was tried by aemilius Frontinus, proconsul at Ephesus; not on account of the Name, but for the robberies which he had committed, being already an apostate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:20
verses.text: Afterwards, having falsely declared for the name of the Lord, he was released, having deceived the faithful that were there.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:21
verses.text: And his own parish, from which he came, did not receive him, because he was a robber.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:22
verses.text: Those who wish to learn about him have the public records of Asia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:23
verses.text: And yet the prophet with whom he spent many years knows nothing about him!.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:24
verses.text: Exposing him, through him we expose also the pretense of the prophet.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:25
verses.text: We could show the same thing of many others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:26
verses.text: But if they are confident, let them endure the test".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:27
verses.text: Again, in another part of his work he speaks as follows of the prophets of whom they boast:  "If they deny that their prophets have received gifts, let them acknowledge this: that if they are convicted of receiving them, they are not prophets.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:28
verses.text: And we will bring a multitude of proofs of this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:29
verses.text: But it is necessary that all the fruits of a prophet should be examined.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:30
verses.text: Tell me, does a prophet dye his hair? Does a prophet stain his eyelids? Does a prophet delight in adornment? Does a prophet play with tables and dice? Does a prophet lend on usury? Let them confess whether these things are lawful or not; but I will show that they have been done by them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:31
verses.text: This same Apollonius states in the same work that, at the time of his writing, it was the fortieth year since Montanus had begun his pretended prophecy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:32
verses.text: And he says also that Zoticus, who was mentioned by the former writer, when Maximilla was pretending to prophesy in Pepuza, resisted her and endeavored to refute the spirit that was working in her; but was prevented by those who agreed with her.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:33
verses.text: He mentions also a certain Thraseas among the martyrs of that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:34
verses.text: He speaks, moreover, of a tradition that the Saviour commanded his apostles not to depart from Jerusalem for twelve years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:35
verses.text: He uses testimonies also from the Revelation of John, and he relates that a dead man had, through the Divine power, been raised by John himself in Ephesus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:36
verses.text: He also adds other things by which he fully and abundantly exposes the error of the heresy of which we have been speaking.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 19:37
verses.text: These are the matters recorded by Apollonius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:2
verses.text: â€”Serapion on the Heresy of the Phrygians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:3
verses.text: Serapion, who, as report says, succeeded Maximinus at that time as bishop of the church of Antioch, mentions the works of Apolinarius against the above-mentioned heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:4
verses.text: And he alludes to him in a private letter to Caricus and Pontius, in which he himself exposes the same heresy, and adds the following words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:5
verses.text: "That you may see that the doings of this lying band of the new prophecy, so called, are an abomination to all the brotherhood throughout the world, I have sent you writings of the most blessed Claudius Apolinarius, bishop of Hierapolis in Asia".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:6
verses.text: In the same letter of Serapion the signatures of several bishops are found, one of whom subscribes himself as follows:  "I, Aurelius Cyrenius, a witness, pray for your health".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:7
verses.text: And another in this manner:  "aelius Publius Julius, bishop of Debeltum, a colony of Thrace.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:8
verses.text: As God liveth in the heavens, the blessed Sotas in Anchialus desired to cast the demon out of Priscilla, but the hypocrites did not permit him".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:9
verses.text: And the autograph signatures of many other bishops who agreed with them are contained in the same letter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 20:10
verses.text: So much for these persons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:2
verses.text: â€”The Writings of Irenaeus against the Schismatics at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:3
verses.text: Irenaeus wrote several letters against those who were disturbing the sound ordinance of the Church at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:4
verses.text: One of them was to Blastus On Schism; another to Florinus On Monarchy, or That God is not the Author of Evil.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:5
verses.text: For Florinus seemed to be defending this opinion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:6
verses.text: And because he was being drawn away by the error of Valentinus, Irenaeus wrote his work On the Ogdoad, in which he shows that he himself had been acquainted with the first successors of the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:7
verses.text: At the close of the treatise we have found a most beautiful note which we are constrained to insert in this work.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:8
verses.text: It runs as follows:  "I adjure thee who mayest copy this book, by our Lord Jesus Christ, and by his glorious advent when he comes to judge the living and the dead, to compare what thou shalt write, and correct it carefully by this manuscript, and also to write this adjuration, and place it in the copy".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:9
verses.text: These things may be profitably read in his work, and related by us, that we may have those ancient and truly holy men as the best example of painstaking carefulness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:10
verses.text: In the letter to Florinus, of which we have spoken, Irenaeus mentions again his intimacy with Polycarp, saying:  "These doctrines, O Florinus, to speak mildly, are not of sound judgment.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:11
verses.text: These doctrines disagree with the Church, and drive into the greatest impiety those who accept them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:12
verses.text: These doctrines, not even the heretics outside of the Church, have ever dared to publish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:13
verses.text: These doctrines, the presbyters who were before us, and who were companions of the apostles, did not deliver to thee.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:14
verses.text: "For when I was a boy, I saw thee in lower Asia with Polycarp, moving in splendor in the royal court, and endeavoring to gain his approbation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:15
verses.text: I remember the events of that time more clearly than those of recent years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:16
verses.text: For what boys learn, growing with their mind, becomes joined with it; so that I am able to describe the very place in which the blessed Polycarp sat as he discoursed, and his goings out and his comings in, and the manner of his life, and his physical appearance, and his discourses to the people, and the accounts which he gave of his intercourse with John and with the others who had seen the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:17
verses.text: And as he remembered their words, and what he heard from them concerning the Lord, and concerning his miracles and his teaching, having received them from eyewitnesses of the 'Word of life,' Polycarp related all things in harmony with the Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:18
verses.text: These things being told me by the mercy of God, I listened to them attentively, noting them down, not on paper, but in my heart.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:19
verses.text: And continually, through God's grace, I recall them faithfully.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:20
verses.text: And I am able to bear witness before God that if that blessed and apostolic presbyter had heard any such thing, he would have cried out, and stopped his ears, and as was his custom, would have exclaimed, O good God, unto what times hast thou spared me that I should endure these things? And he would have fled from the place where, sitting or standing, he had heard such words.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:21
verses.text: And this can be shown plainly from the letters which he sent, either to the neighboring churches for their confirmation, or to some of the brethren, admonishing and exhorting them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 21:22
verses.text: Thus far Irenaeus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:2
verses.text: â€”How Appolonius suffered Martyrdom at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:3
verses.text: About the same time, in the reign of Commodus, our condition became more favorable, and through the grace of God the churches throughout the entire world enjoyed peace, and the word of salvation was leading every soul, from every race of man to the devout worship of the God of the universe.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:4
verses.text: So that now at Rome many who were highly distinguished for wealth and family turned with all their household and relatives unto their salvation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:5
verses.text: But the demon who hates what is good, being malignant in his nature, could not endure this, but prepared himself again for conflict, contriving many devices against us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:6
verses.text: And he brought to the judgment seat Apollonius, of the city of Rome, a man renowned among the faithful for learning and philosophy, having stirred up one of his servants, who was well fitted for such a purpose, to accuse him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:7
verses.text: But this wretched man made the charge unseasonably, because by a royal decree it was unlawful that informers of such things should live.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:8
verses.text: And his legs were broken immediately, Perennius the judge having pronounced this sentence upon him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:9
verses.text: But the martyr, highly beloved of God, being earnestly entreated and requested by the judge to give an account of himself before the Senate, made in the presence of all an eloquent defense of the faith for which he was witnessing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:10
verses.text: And as if by decree of the Senate he was put to death by decapitation; an ancient law requiring that those who were brought to the judgment seat and refused to recant should not be liberated.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 22:11
verses.text: Whoever desires to know his arguments before the judge and his answers to the questions of Perennius, and his entire defense before the Senate will find them in the records of the ancient martyrdoms which we have collected.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:2
verses.text: â€”The Bishops that were well known at this Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:3
verses.text: In the tenth year of the reign of Commodus, Victor succeeded Eleutherus, the latter having held the episcopate for thirteen years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:4
verses.text: In the same year, after Julian had completed his tenth year, Demetrius received the charge of the parishes at Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:5
verses.text: At this time the above-mentioned Serapion, the eighth from the apostles, was still well known as bishop of the church at Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:6
verses.text: Theophilus presided at Caesarea in Palestine; and Narcissus, whom we have mentioned before, still had charge of the church at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:7
verses.text: Bacchylus at the same time was bishop of Corinth in Greece, and Polycrates of the parish of Ephesus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:8
verses.text: And besides these a multitude of others, as is likely, were then prominent.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 23:9
verses.text: But we have given the names of those alone, the soundness of whose faith has come down to us in writing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:2
verses.text: â€”The Question then agitated concerning the Passover.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:3
verses.text: A question of no small importance arose at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:4
verses.text: For the parishes of all Asia, as from an older tradition, held that the fourteenth day of the moon, on which day the Jews were commanded to sacrifice the lamb, should be observed as the feast of the Saviour's passover.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:5
verses.text: It was therefore necessary to end their fast on that day, whatever day of the week it should happen to be.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:6
verses.text: But it was not the custom of the churches in the rest of the world to end it at this time, as they observed the practice which, from apostolic tradition, has prevailed to the present time, of terminating the fast on no other day than on that of the resurrection of our Saviour.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:7
verses.text: Synods and assemblies of bishops were held on this account, and all, with one consent, through mutual correspondence drew up an ecclesiastical decree, that the mystery of the resurrection of the Lord should be celebrated on no other but the Lord's day, and that we should observe the close of the paschal fast on this day only.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:8
verses.text: There is still extant a writing of those who were then assembled in Palestine, over whom Theophilus, bishop of Caesarea, and Narcissus, bishop of Jerusalem, presided.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:9
verses.text: And there is also another writing extant of those who were assembled at Rome to consider the same question, which bears the name of Bishop Victor; also of the bishops in Pontus over whom Palmas, as the oldest, presided; and of the parishes in Gaul of which Irenaeus was bishop, and of those in OsrhoÃ«ne and the cities there; and a personal letter of Bacchylus, bishop of the church at Corinth, and of a great many others, who uttered the same opinion and judgment, and cast the same vote.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 24:10
verses.text: And that which has been given above was their unanimous decision.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:2
verses.text: â€”The Disagreement in Asia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:3
verses.text: But the bishops of Asia, led by Polycrates, decided to hold to the old custom handed down to them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:4
verses.text: He himself, in a letter which he addressed to Victor and the church of Rome, set forth in the following words the tradition which had come down to him:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:5
verses.text: "We observe the exact day; neither adding, nor taking away.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:6
verses.text: For in Asia also great lights have fallen asleep, which shall rise again on the day of the Lord's coming, when he shall come with glory from heaven, and shall seek out all the saints.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:7
verses.text: Among these are Philip, one of the twelve apostles, who fell asleep in Hierapolis; and his two aged virgin daughters, and another daughter, who lived in the Holy Spirit and now rests at Ephesus; and, moreover, John, who was both a witness and a teacher, who reclined upon the bosom of the Lord, and, being a priest, wore the sacerdotal plate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:8
verses.text: He fell asleep at Ephesus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:9
verses.text: And Polycarp in Smyrna, who was a bishop and martyr; and Thraseas, bishop and martyr from Eumenia, who fell asleep in Smyrna.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:10
verses.text: Why need I mention the bishop and martyr Sagaris who fell asleep in Laodicea, or the blessed Papirius, or Melito, the Eunuch who lived altogether in the Holy Spirit, and who lies in Sardis, awaiting the episcopate from heaven, when he shall rise from the dead?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:11
verses.text: All these observed the fourteenth day of the passover according to the Gospel, deviating in no respect, but following the rule of faith.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:12
verses.text: And I also, Polycrates, the least of you all, do according to the tradition of my relatives, some of whom I have closely followed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:13
verses.text: For seven of my relatives were bishops; and I am the eighth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:14
verses.text: And my relatives always observed the day when the people put away the leaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:15
verses.text: I, therefore, brethren, who have lived sixty-five years in the Lord, and have met with the brethren throughout the world, and have gone through every Holy Scripture, am not affrighted by terrifying words.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:16
verses.text: For those greater than I have said 'We ought to obey God rather than man.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:18
verses.text: He then writes of all the bishops who were present with him and thought as he did.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:19
verses.text: His words are as follows:  "I could mention the bishops who were present, whom I summoned at your desire; whose names, should I write them, would constitute a great multitude.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:20
verses.text: And they, beholding my littleness, gave their consent to the letter, knowing that I did not bear my gray hairs in vain, but had always governed my life by the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:21
verses.text: Thereupon Victor, who presided over the church at Rome, immediately attempted to cut off from the common unity the parishes of all Asia, with the churches that agreed with them, as heterodox; and he wrote letters and declared all the brethren there wholly excommunicate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:22
verses.text: But this did not please all the bishops.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:23
verses.text: And they besought him to consider the things of peace, and of neighborly unity and love.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:24
verses.text: Words of theirs are extant, sharply rebuking Victor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:25
verses.text: Among them was Irenaeus, who, sending letters in the name of the brethren in Gaul over whom he presided, maintained that the mystery of the resurrection of the Lord should be observed only on the Lord's day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:26
verses.text: He fittingly admonishes Victor that he should not cut off whole churches of God which observed the tradition of an ancient custom and after many other words he proceeds as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:27
verses.text: "For the controversy is not only concerning the day, but also concerning the very manner of the fast.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:28
verses.text: For some think that they should fast one day, others two, yet others more; some, moreover, count their day as consisting of forty hours day and night.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:29
verses.text: And this variety in its observance has not originated in our time; but long before in that of our ancestors.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:30
verses.text: It is likely that they did not hold to strict accuracy, and thus formed a custom for their posterity according to their own simplicity and peculiar mode.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:31
verses.text: Yet all of these lived none the less in peace, and we also live in peace with one another; and the disagreement in regard to the fast confirms the agreement in the faith".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:32
verses.text: He adds to this the following account, which I may properly insert:  "Among these were the presbyters before Soter, who presided over the church which thou now rulest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:33
verses.text: We mean Anicetus, and Pius, and Hyginus, and Telesphorus, and Xystus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:34
verses.text: They neither observed it themselves, nor did they permit those after them to do so.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:35
verses.text: And yet though not observing it, they were none the less at peace with those who came to them from the parishes in which it was observed; although this observance was more opposed to those who did not observe it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:36
verses.text: But none were ever cast out on account of this form; but the presbyters before thee who did not observe it, sent the eucharist to those of other parishes who observed it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:37
verses.text: And when the blessed Polycarp was at Rome in the time of Anicetus, and they disagreed a little about certain other things, they immediately made peace with one another, not caring to quarrel over this matter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:38
verses.text: For neither could Anicetus persuade Polycarp not to observe what he had always observed with John the disciple of our Lord, and the other apostles with whom he had associated; neither could Polycarp persuade Anicetus to observe it as he said that he ought to follow the customs of the presbyters that had preceded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:39
verses.text: But though matters were in this shape, they communed together, and Anicetus conceded the administration of the eucharist in the church to Polycarp, manifestly as a mark of respect.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:40
verses.text: And they parted from each other in peace, both those who observed, and those who did not, maintaining the peace of the whole church".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:41
verses.text: Thus Irenaeus, who truly was well named, became a peacemaker in this matter, exhorting and negotiating in this way in behalf of the peace of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 25:42
verses.text: And he conferred by letter about this mooted question, not only with Victor, but also with most of the other rulers of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:2
verses.text: â€”How All came to an Agreement respecting the Passover.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:3
verses.text: Those in Palestine whom we have recently mentioned, Narcissus and Theophilus, and with them Cassius, bishop of the church of Tyre, and Clarus of the church of Ptolemais, and those who met with them, having stated many things respecting the tradition concerning the passover which had come to them in succession from the apostles, at the close of their writing add these words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:4
verses.text: "Endeavor to send copies of our letter to every church, that we may not furnish occasion to those who easily deceive their souls.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:5
verses.text: We show you indeed that also in Alexandria they keep it on the same day that we do.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 26:6
verses.text: For letters are carried from us to them and from them to us, so that in the same manner and at the same time we keep the sacred day".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 27:2
verses.text: â€”The Elegant Works of Irenaeus which have come down to us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 27:3
verses.text: Besides the works and letters of Irenaeus which we have mentioned, a certain book of his On Knowledge, written against the Greeks, very concise and remarkably forcible, is extant; and another, which he dedicated to a brother Marcian, In Demonstration of the Apostolic Preaching; and a volume containing various Dissertations, in which he mentions the Epistle to the Hebrews and the so-called Wisdom of Solomon, making quotations from them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 27:4
verses.text: These are the works of Irenaeus which have come to our knowledge.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 27:5
verses.text: Commodus having ended his reign after thirteen years, Severus became emperor in less than six months after his death, Pertinax having reigned during the intervening time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:2
verses.text: â€”The Works of Others that flourished at that Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:3
verses.text: Numerous memorials of the faithful zeal of the ancient ecclesiastical men of that time are still preserved by many.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:4
verses.text: Of these we would note particularly the writings of Heraclitus On the Apostle, and those of Maximus on the question so much discussed among heretics, the Origin of Evil, and on the Creation of Matter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:5
verses.text: Also those of Candidus on the Hexaemeron, and of Apion on the same subject; likewise of Sextus on the Resurrection, and another treatise of Arabianus, and writings of a multitude of others, in regard to whom, because we have no data, it is impossible to state in our work when they lived, or to give any account of their history.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 28:6
verses.text: And works of many others have come down to us whose names we are unable to give, orthodox and ecclesiastical, as their interpretations of the Divine Scriptures show, but unknown to us, because their names are not stated in their writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:2
verses.text: â€”Those who first advanced the Heresy of Artemon; their Manner of Life, and how they dared to corrupt the Sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:3
verses.text: In a laborious work by one of these writers against the heresy of Artemon, which Paul of Samosata attempted to revive again in our day, there is an account appropriate to the history which we are now examining.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:4
verses.text: For he criticises, as a late innovation, the above-mentioned heresy which teaches that the Saviour was a mere man, because they were attempting to magnify it as ancient.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:5
verses.text: Having given in his work many other arguments in refutation of their blasphemous falsehood, he adds the following words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:6
verses.text: "For they say that all the early teachers and the apostles received and taught what they now declare, and that the truth of the Gospel was preserved until the times of Victor, who was the thirteenth bishop of Rome from Peter, but that from his successor, Zephyrinus, the truth had been corrupted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:7
verses.text: And what they say might be plausible, if first of all the Divine Scriptures did not contradict them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:8
verses.text: And there are writings of certain brethren older than the times of Victor, which they wrote in behalf of the truth against the heathen, and against the heresies which existed in their day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:9
verses.text: I refer to Justin and Miltiades and Tatian and Clement and many others, in all of whose works Christ is spoken of as God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:10
verses.text: For who does not know the works of Irenaeus and of Melito and of others which teach that Christ is God and man? And how many psalms and hymns, written by the faithful brethren from the beginning, celebrate Christ the Word of God, speaking of him as Divine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:11
verses.text: How then since the opinion held by the Church has been preached for so many years, can its preaching have been delayed as they affirm, until the times of Victor? And how is it that they are not ashamed to speak thus falsely of Victor, knowing well that he cut off from communion Theodotus, the cobbler, the leader and father of this God-denying apostasy, and the first to declare that Christ is mere man? For if Victor agreed with their opinions, as their slander affirms, how came he to cast out Theodotus, the inventor of this heresy?".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:12
verses.text: So much in regard to Victor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:13
verses.text: His bishopric lasted ten years, and Zephyrinus was appointed his successor about the ninth year of the reign of Severus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:14
verses.text: The author of the above-mentioned book, concerning the founder of this heresy, narrates another event which occurred in the time of Zephyrinus, using these words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:15
verses.text: "I will remind many of the brethren of a fact which took place in our time, which, had it happened in Sodom, might, I think, have proved a warning to them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:16
verses.text: There was a certain confessor, Natalius, not long ago, but in our own day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:17
verses.text: This man was deceived at one time by Asclepiodotus and another Theodotus, a money-changer.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:18
verses.text: Both of them were disciples of Theodotus, the cobbler, who, as I have said, was the first person excommunicated by Victor, bishop at that time, on account of this sentiment, or rather senselessness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:19
verses.text: Natalius was persuaded by them to allow himself to be chosen bishop of this heresy with a salary, to be paid by them, of one hundred and fifty denarii a month.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:20
verses.text: When he had thus connected himself with them, he was warned oftentimes by the Lord through visions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:21
verses.text: For the compassionate God and our Lord Jesus Christ was not willing that a witness of his own sufferings, being cast out of the Church, should perish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:22
verses.text: But as he paid little regard to the visions, because he was ensnared by the first position among them and by that shameful covetousness which destroys a great many, he was scourged by holy angels, and punished severely through the entire night.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:23
verses.text: Thereupon having risen in the morning, he put on sackcloth and covered himself with ashes, and with great haste and tears he fell down before Zephyrinus, the bishop, rolling at the feet not only of the clergy, but also of the laity; and he moved with his tears the compassionate Church of the merciful Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:24
verses.text: And though he used much supplication, and showed the welts of the stripes which he had received, yet scarcely was he taken back into communion".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:25
verses.text: We will add from the same writer some other extracts concerning them, which run as follows:  "They have treated the Divine Scriptures recklessly and without fear.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:26
verses.text: They have set aside the rule of ancient faith; and Christ they have not known.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:27
verses.text: They do not endeavor to learn what the Divine Scriptures declare, but strive laboriously after any form of syllogism which may be devised to sustain their impiety.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:28
verses.text: And if any one brings before them a passage of Divine Scripture, they see whether a conjunctive or disjunctive form of syllogism can be made from it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:29
verses.text: And as being of the earth and speaking of the earth, and as ignorant of him who cometh from above, they forsake the holy writings of God to devote themselves to geometry.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:30
verses.text: Euclid is laboriously measured by some of them; and Aristotle and Theophrastus are admired; and Galen, perhaps, by some is even worshiped.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:31
verses.text: But that those who use the arts of unbelievers for their heretical opinions and adulterate the simple faith of the Divine Scriptures by the craft of the godless, are far from the faith, what need is there to say? Therefore they have laid their hands boldly upon the Divine Scriptures, alleging that they have corrected them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:32
verses.text: That I am not speaking falsely of them in this matter, whoever wishes may learn.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:33
verses.text: For if any one will collect their respective copies, and compare them one with another, he will find that they differ greatly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:34
verses.text: Those of Asclepiades, for example, do not agree with those of Theodotus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:35
verses.text: And many of these can be obtained, because their disciples have assiduously written the corrections, as they call them, that is the corruptions, of each of them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:36
verses.text: Again, those of Hermophilus do not agree with these, and those of Apollonides are not consistent with themselves.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:37
verses.text: For you can compare those prepared by them at an earlier date with those which they corrupted later, and you will find them widely different.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:38
verses.text: But how daring this offense is, it is not likely that they themselves are ignorant.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:39
verses.text: For either they do not believe that the Divine Scriptures were spoken by the Holy Spirit, and thus are unbelievers, or else they think themselves wiser than the Holy Spirit, and in that case what else are they than demoniacs? For they cannot deny the commission of the crime, since the copies have been written by their own hands.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:40
verses.text: For they did not receive such Scriptures from their instructors, nor can they produce any copies from which they were transcribed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:41
verses.text: But some of them have not thought it worth while to corrupt them, but simply deny the law and the prophets, and thus through their lawless and impious teaching under pretense of grace, have sunk to the lowest depths of perdition".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book V 29:42
verses.text: Let this suffice for these things.
